review_title: Much Improved from a few years back
one_reviews_text:
Back in 2018, I hated this product and my review showed it, however, revisting this title on the Quest 2 and Rift S (cross play), has changed my opinon. The coaster physics can still use a lot of improvement (turns are still nauseating), and I hate the idea of a coaster that detaches from its track and lands hundreds of feet away. 

What I do like now, are the improved themes and many more tracks to ride, shoot or race through. The developers have kept up with improvements, and you can see it in some of the older tracks, like the Jurassic-style coaster which is a great show off piece when friends or family are over. Plus, they've added new features like a helmet which blocks some of the surrounding area to resuce VR sickness.  With 18 tracks, there's a lot to ride and the experiences are lengthy. Some themes are meh, while others are pretty impressive! I'm back on board, and hoping the developers continue to add more track and ideas to this wild experience.

I found this game earlier last night and ran through it and realized what an absolute gold mine it is for VR introduction. It is listed as Intense, but it's really moderate to strong. I ran some of my more 'motion sickness' prone siblings/nieces+nephews through this, then intro'd them to a dungeon crawl Save in Skyrim, and they were (mostly) perfectly adjusted with VR sickness. 

I purchased this game's extra rides for $12.99 at an advertised 46% discount... this is 100% worth the purchase. Have your friends/family try these rides first, *leaning into the curves/twists*, and they will be far more likely able to handle any more intense VR motion sickness game, from Rift Skyrim VR to Steam/PSVR Resident Evil 2.

100% serious. No benefits earned from this review or provided beforehand as prior compensation.

I've seen some reviews compaining that the 'jerkiness' of the roller coasters are unrealistic, that there aren't enough build up/escalation times to the peak of the coaster arcs, and other such nonsense. I've never ridden a single perfectly smooth roller coaster ride in my life, and I worked at 2 different Six Flags and various other theme parks. There are one or two jerks per ride, but for the most part, they're fairly relative to the abrupt movements of real roller coasters. The only major flaw I 'felt' where the jumps between broken tracks... that provided a sense of dissonance for me since there are clearly not such track breaks in real life. 

This was worth the purchase on just the enjoyment of the game itself. I have to admit... *** spoiler *** ... the sewers, backwards, that first zombie on the front? Scared me.

review_title: OK as free, wouldn't pay for more
one_reviews_text:
The experience is fun, but only as free ride. As paid experience, I don't think this is really worth it.

Lots of efforts went into this, but this is 2017, and honestly the roller coaster simulation was interesting 5 years ago, when it was a novelty, but at this time; we have full games that offer more than a RC ride, so unless you are Disney or Universal, and are making a free ride viewer to attract people to your park, there is not really much incentive to spend money for something that you watch once, and then it is purely for show to your friends that never saw VR experiences before.

The app is well done, and devs did a great job, hence the 3 stars, but beyond that, this product offer virtually nothing more than a brief experience; which I am not sure anyone would even plan to spend money on it.

As free product, the ride is cool as tech demo, but you will use it once and be done with it, until your friends show up.

They obviously worked a lot on the graphics and it was pretty smooth with a decent sense of speed.  The whole island on the free track still felt a bit empty besides the lame waterfall effects everywhere.  But the textures and lighting are pretty good, and the track looks nice with the wheels on the coaster exposed.  The hill climbs were sometimes painfully long and I didn't feel like the coaster ever kept up its speed for long enough to get truly immersed before it climbed another hill.

As for the DLC, I did not buy any, but I think it would do the company a lot of good to list "1 track free, 3.99 per additional track" and mention there are 4 tracks total, 3 being pay.  3.99 is a fair enough price, though I think you could also do a 9.99 deal for all 3 and get way more takers. 

Overall this product showed more care than I was expecting going in and it's worth a single trip on the free coaster to see it.
